Title: Mapping the Deprived Visual System: Cracking function for prediction (MADVIS)

The MADVIS project aims to elucidate the effects of visual deprivation on the organization and connectivity of the occipital cortex at different developmental stages. By understanding how the brain adapts to the absence of visual input, we can develop predictive tools for sight restoration outcomes. Our interdisciplinary approach combines cognitive neurosciences and ophthalmology to investigate the relationship between crossmodal plasticity and sight recovery. We will employ innovative methods to study the brain's ability to reorganize and adapt in response to sensory deprivation. The project's objectives are twofold: first, to determine how visual deprivation affects the occipital cortex's organization and connectivity, and second, to leverage this knowledge to predict outcomes of sight restoration. The expected impact of MADVIS is threefold: advancing our understanding of experience-dependent shaping of brain regions, bridging the gap between crossmodal reorganization and sight restoration, and developing new predictive tools for sensory restoration procedures. By cracking the code of the deprived visual system, we can ultimately improve outcomes for individuals undergoing sight restoration procedures.
